awd_titl_txt: Biological Clocks and Social Organization Symposium   Meeting Dates: July 3 through 8, 2022 in San Diego, CA.
awd_abstract_narration:
This symposium focuses on biological clocks and social behavior in social insects and takes place at the 2022 International Union for the Study of Social Insects (IUSSI), in San Diego, California. Invited presenters will bring together information on distinct technologies and insights as related to biological clocks and how they interact with social behavior. This symposium, and IUSSI, presents a unique opportunity to bring researchers together to facilitate synergy, professional development, future research collaborations, and a better understanding of the economically important social insects. Presenters represent a broad range of career stages and fields and there is strong participation of individuals from groups traditionally underrepresented in STEM fields. Undergraduate students will also attend the IUSSI providing a valuable early career experience. 

Biological clocks organize aspects of life at different levels of biological organization. Participants in this symposium and the focused meetings around this symposium will help form a deeper understanding of social insects, social behavior, and biological clocks potentially leading to new frontiers of research and understanding. Also, of interest and focus here is seasonal timing of behavior and how the adaptive nature of seasonal behaviors could be impacted by climate changes. Planned publications will share the synergistic outcomes of the symposium.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported the first in-person symposium after the pandemic to examine biological clocks and social behavior at the 2022 International Union for the Study of Social Insects (IUSSI), in San Diego, California. . Biological clocks organize aspects of life at different levels of biological organization, from daily activities to seasonal timing of behavior. Adaptive nature of seasonal behaviors could be impacted by climate change.  A deeper understanding of social insects, social behavior, and biological clocks will lead to new frontiers of research and understanding to tackle problems of adapting to a changing environment. In this symposium 22 researchers from 7 countries communicated new findings that resulted in 1) defining research directions in social, seasonal, and organismal clock mechanisms in the field named “Sociochronobiology”; 2) a novel effort for international scientists to examine potential global collaborations that can apply basic research findings to improve climate response.

The role of biological clocks in organization of highly eusocial insects is increasingly better understood.  Yet deeper understanding is developing in new frontiers such as asking questions on detailed clock regulatory mechanisms and functional, social role of individual differences in biological rhythms.  One big question, in the clock field, is how the daily clock may serve seasonal patterns.  Yet adaptiveness of seasonal patterns is threatened by climate change. There is additionally a practical significance to this topic, since for social insects, including the main agricultural pollinators, honey bees, climate change brings challenges to survive seasonal changes.

The symposium during the 5-day meeting resulted in developing key research directions, highlighting significant findings, and beginning of international collaborations.  The research directions included: a. Levels of sociality and associated differences in circadian rhythms and mechanisms, and b. Core gut microbiota in social vs solitary organisms and its relation to circadian rhythms.  The collaborations included developing novel neuroimaging methods and application of gene targeting to non-traditional model organisms.  After the symposium a special issue in the journal Peer J, titled: “Biological Clocks and Social Organization” was prepared to disseminate the results broadly.

 

The impact on students and researchers amplified because the symposium helped overcome the barriers resulting from COVID 19 pandemic conditions to the networking and collaboration opportunities. The symposium and roundtable resulted in graduate and undergraduate students in the field of sociochronobiology to begin collaborations and progress in their research following the COVID pandemic.

 

The broader impacts of this project have been three-fold. First, the project contributed to professional development of young scientists in this field through networking, publications, and collaborations. Second, the project enabled sharing the currently available work on sociochronobiology, which extends from invertebrates to vertebrates and social, seasonal, and organismal clock mechanisms. The interdisciplinary approach and tools will permit in depth investigations of the influence of climate change on organisms and their interactions. Third, the project resulted in outlining a strategic research direction, collaboration, and dissemination plan for the field. The new research directions and international collaborations are expected to translate into applied benefits for the challenge of a changing world.
